desc: RAD54L encodes a protein involved in DNA double-strand break repair. Mutations of RAD54L are found in non-Hodgkin lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia, among other cancers.

RAD54L is a member of the RAD52 epistasis group and is important in homologous recombination and DNA double-strand break repair. Double-strand breaks in DNA are potentially the most problematic DNA damage event for a cell to resolve. Unrepaired or misrepaired double-strand lesions can be lethal or oncogenic to the cell. The cell repairs these defects primarily through homologous recombination or nonhomologous end joining. RAD54L is critical for the efficient repair of double stranded DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. RAD54L is a SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling family member, in particular the SNF2-family of helicases. Although the SNF2 family members have motifs that identify them as helicases, none have been shown to posses the ability to unwind duplex DNA into single strands, as other helicase do. They function as motor proteins, translocation along double-stranded DNA, performing specific chromatin remodeling tasks, inducing topological changes in the DNA, and interacting with other proteins to effect recombination (PMID: 11459989, 16818238). These biochemical activities of RAD54L occur during homologous recombination double-strand DNA break repair and are enhanced in the context of RAD51 bound ssDNA/dsDNA (PMID: 11030338, 12359723). In a reciprocal effect the RAD51 nucleofilament is stabilized in the presence of RAD54L (PMID: 12566442) during the initiation of homologous recombination. In addition, RAD54L can disassociate RAD51 from duplex DNA. (PMID: 12453424). There is preliminary evidence that RAD54L can function as a chromatin remodeler, presumably in the context pre-synaptic double-strand DNA break repair (PMID: 17417655, 19671661). Despite the abundance of biochemical and genetic data on RAD54L, the details of its role(s) in recombination are still being elucidated. Point mutations in RAD54L are predicted to have a variety of effects, depending on the location and nature of the mutation.
